title-group.article-title: ‘Obstructive sleep apnea is associated with fatigue in multiple sclerosis’ by Kaminska et al.

body.p: We have read with interest the recent publication by Kaminska et al.1 who reported obstructive sleep apnoea (OSA) in 36 of 62 multiple sclerosis (MS) patients (58.1%) which was similar to control individuals (15 of 32; 46.9%).

The predominant type of event was obstructive hypopnoea with arousal but not with desaturation. Severe fatigue (Fatigue Severity Scale (FSS) ≥ 5.0) was associated with OSA and respiratory related arousals only in MS, but not in controls.

In our recent cross-sectional polysomnography (PSG) trial2 only 8 out of 66 MS patients (12.1%) suffered from sleep-related breathing disorders (SRBD) (OSA, n = 6; central sleep apnoea, n = 1; central alveolar hypoventilation, n = 1), and 7 out of these 8 SRBD patients had severe fatigue.

How can we explain this difference in frequency of SRBD between the studies? First, we used a home-based PSG system in the patient’s habitual sleeping environment in order to minimize selection bias and to encourage as many patients as possible to participate in our study whereas the Montreal group1 used in-lab PSG. We had a selected sample of patients in our study: 66 out of 141 enrolled patients agreed to undergo PSG. The Montreal group described that recruitment occurred between July 2007 and February 2010 but information on patients who refused to participate in the study was not recorded. Differences in recruitment strategies may partly account for the difference in SRBD frequencies.

However, we have to look deeper into this issue: in our study classification of sleep stages took place in accordance with Rechtschaffen and Kales (R&K)3 on the basis of C3/C4-EEG electrodes. The 1999 criteria from the American Academy of Sleep Medicine (AASM) Task Force4 were used for scoring respiratory events.

In contrast, the Montreal study used the new AASM criteria5 for scoring sleep on the basis of C4/C3/F3/F4/O1/O2 EEG electrodes but especially respiratory analysis has been still based on the older 1999 AASM criteria,4 which is of particular importance as the use of different EEG electrodes may cause differences in scoring arousals.

It is important to note that according to the 1999 AASM Task Force criteria, both studies scored an apnoea as an airflow cessation for ≥10 seconds and a hypopnoea as airflow reduction for ≥10 seconds by ≥50%, or associated with arousal or desaturation ≥4%. In both studies pressure sensor for flow signal was used, but not oesophageal pressure as the preferred method to assess changes in respiratory effort. Therefore, despite the standardization of methods, the manner to assess respiratory arousal (EEG electrodes, manual scoring and software used) may have differed and may thus have influenced the resulting apnoea–hypopnoea index.

Considering only the apnoea–hypopnoea–desaturation index in the Montreal group (without classifying arousal-associated hypopnoea), only 7 out of 62 MS patients (11%) suffered from OSA, what is very similar to our study (12.1%).

In summary, we assume that both patient selection and methodological differences in PSG performance and assessment of arousals may account for the differences in prevalence of OSA between the two cohorts.
